Thanks to all who responded. 
   
  The funny thing is I just came back from Japan last week. I spent 3 days in Kyoto and 4 in Tokyo. I wish I had known of some places to go to before I left. Oh, well that will only encourage me to go back to find these shops next time.

  Thanks Again
  Anthony
Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
  Hi Anthony, and welcome to the list. I can personally recommend the 
following dealers ( as I have has experience with them )

In the US.

Fred Wesiberg - http://www.nihonto.com/contents.html

Andrew Quirt - http://www.nihonto.us/

And in Japan

Seikeido ( they speak excellent english ) - http://www.seikeido.com/

Ginza Choshuya ( they speak excellent english ) - 
http://world.choshuya.co.jp/

and  the Fine Sword Company ( they also speak english ) - 
http://www.finesword.co.jp/

All carry excellent tsuba and Fine Sword have a good cross range of 
prices as well.

You idea is sound, stay away from Ebay unless you are very sure of 
yourself and your knowledge. Jim Gilbert's site 9 
http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/tsuba.htm )  has a good list of 
tsuba books under the **Bibliography* 
<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Ejggilbert/reading.htm>* link to chase down 
as well. mmmm, for every 3 - 4 books I buy it seems, I miss a tsuba... :-)

Cheers

Richard







anwahi wrote:

>Hello,
>
>I'm new here and to collecting Tsuba. Where do you buy your Tsuba from? 
>I know there's several websites you can find with a Google search, an 
>occasional Token Kai show like the one in SF, or Ebay (most look like 
>junk). I'm looking for good sources of authentic Tsuba. Obviously the 
>only way to be really sure of authenticity is to purchase papered 
>Tsuba, but because I'm starting off I want some sources of authentic 
>Tsuba more reasonably priced. Any suggestions?
>
>Thanks for your helpo in advance,
>Anthony
